Feb. 4, 1937.
Dear Family:
Flying from Shanghai to Hongkongâ€¢
We had to wait at Shanghai for two hours account of heavy fog on the
river at our first port of call - Wenchow.
The first hundred miles
south of Shanghai is over flat country densely populated alluvial
delta land cross laced by innumerable small canals which serve alike
for transportation and for irrigation.
This country is all cultivated
a once a year crop in this section.
one not yet planted.
We have just flown over Ningpo, important
treaty port open to foreign trade,
famous for its sailors, missionaries
and Ningpo varnish which is used
extensively by furniture makers
which when not properly dried will give tender skins a rash much like
poison ivy.
In Shanghai the pidgin English for "South" is "Ningpo more
which means any point below Ningpo.
As we fly
"Ningpo more far"
the brown rice fields give way to low
rolling country
part rice and
The
tea bushes are
planted in little terraced plots of
ground up the mountainsides and
from the air it is usually hard to
listinguish the rice land from tea but at this time of year
remain green while the rice fields are bare.
As we fly
South the mountains rise up to 4000 feet,
jagged,
sawtooth peaks
by mountain streams
which erode
great canyons
through the tree-less
unprotected
mountainsides, filling up with soil
from the hillsides
narrow valleys which are cultivated closely.
While forest volunteers
have attempted to recapture the mountains which once were theirs,
Chinese peasants, for some reason unknown to me, light fires and burn
scrub timber even though no use is made of the burnt
over Lane.
they gather the charcoal or maybe they find protection
is improved by the elimination of
cover - but whatever
reason it seems almost criminal.
Messrs. Trippe and Whitney who have flown pretty much every-
where both said that the scenic beauty
of the flight from Hongkong
surpassed any
they had seen elsewhere.
Great masses of stone,
deep narrow canyons cut from the solid rock,
five hundred foot high
smooth moss like hills and this morning the valleys filled
in spots with fog the color of dirty cotton floating as though poured
the
valleys by the Gods.
Here we are flying at 5000 feet in a
sunlit sky - no clouds, only an Arizona blue in the dome from horizon
to horizon yet our last weather report from Wenchow reports
If the fog does not move out of our way
- or unere are
through which we can fly down
to land on the river, we shall
pass up Wenchow and continue on to Foochow.
We have just flown over Fenghua a small town where our amah,
Tsing Tzu came from and possibly more entitled to fame as the home of
Chiang Kai-shek,
whose private airport lies below us.
The Generalissimo
there recuperating from his harrowing experiences at Sian-fu.
It is said on good authority that after his imprisonment at Sian-fu
he refused to confer with his captor Chang Hsuch-liang but quietly said
"You are my
otherwise you are
no reason for conferences."
Chiang Kai-shek is proud, fearless, ruth-
less yet patient.
He has given his life to the unification of China-
an almost,
ed
if not entirely, impossible task.
How heart sick,
disillusion
and altogether miserable he must have been, caged, humiliated,
and
bullied by a big headed, swashbuckling subordinate who was actuated by
motives almost wholly selfish.
It's the old old game of China.
No
player will sacrifice the right of individual action for the sake of
team play. No player wants to run interference but each wants to carry
the ball
every
play and if anyone on his side is stupid enough to form
interference for him that's OK.
Chinese have been individualistic for
